titleStmt.title: Second-Order Locally Dynamical Consensus of Multiagent Systems With Arbitrarily Fast Switching Directed Topologies

affiliation.orgName: College of Electronics and Infor-mation Engineering

analytic.title: Second-Order Locally Dynamical Consensus of Multiagent Systems With Arbitrarily Fast Switching Directed Topologies

biblStruct.note: received March 26, 2012; revised September 7, 2012; accepted November 30, 2012.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper is mainly concerned with the analysis of the second-order locally dynamical consensus of multiagent systems with nonlinear dynamics in the directed networks with arbitrarily fast switching topologies. In our designed framework, the time-varying network topology is constant in each time interval and then randomly jumps to another topology when certain occasional events occur at some random moments. In addition, we further assume that the dwell time of each topology is unknown in advance and the corresponding adjacency weighted matrix is not necessarily nonnegative due to the probable existence of deteriorated communication channels in the underlying interaction network. By the orthogonal decomposition method, the state vector of the resultant error dynamical system can be further decomposed as two transversal components, one of which evolves along the consensus manifold and the other evolves transversally with the consensus manifold. Then, by introducing the generalized matrix measure and by applying the tools of contraction and circle analysis, the second-order locally dynamical consensus of multiagent systems with arbitrarily fast switching directed topologies is theoretically investigated in detail, and some easily verified sufficient conditions are also presented. It is shown that, under sufficiently large coupling strengths, the random switchings can be effectively tolerated and the consensus can be achieved for all agents in the network. Finally, numerical simulation examples are also provided to demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of the obtained theoretical results.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: I N RECENT years, the collective behaviors of multiagent systems have attracted extensive attention due to the growing interest in animal group behaviors [1]. Numerous issues have also been addressed such as consensus problem [2]- [4], [32], [33], [35]- [37], formation control [5], and so on. A fundamental approach to make the states of multiagent systems reach an agreement on a common value of interest is consensus analysis. Roughly speaking, the consensus problem generally means how to design network interaction protocols (or called algorithms) based on local information of nodes' dynamics such that all of the agents asymptotically or even exponentially reach an agreement on their states. At present, the consensus problem has attracted extensive attention in different research fields due to its broad applications in cooperative control of unmanned air vehicles [11], formation control of mobile robots [5], [34], control of communication networks [7], management science and statistics [8], system and control [9], [31], flocking of social insects [10], swarm-based computing [6], and so on.

In the past decade, numerous studies had been conducted on the consensus problem for multiagent networks with first-order linear dynamics, [2], [3], [5], [11]- [14]. A framework of consensus problem in networked dynamical agents was established in [12] by Olfati-Saber and Murray. In [13], Jadbabaie et al. further discussed the linearized Vicsek's model and obtained that consensus can always be reached as long as the switching topology is periodically jointly connected or ultimately connected. In [15], Ren et al. extended the results of [12] and [13] and presented some more less restrictive conditions for reaching consensus of agents under dynamically varying interaction topologies. However, when the driving force (acceleration) is introduced as the control input in practical systems, each agent should be modeled by a double-integrator dynamical system. Moreover, in reality, a broad class of harmonic oscillators [16] and pendulums [17] is second-order dynamical models, which are governed by both position and velocity terms. In contrast to the first-order consensus problem, it has been shown that consensus may fail to be achieved for agents with the secondorder dynamics even if the network topology has a directed spanning tree [18]. The consensus problem of double-integrator agent systems has also been studied extensively in [4], [6], [16], and [18], to name a few. By the existing literature, we know that consensus of the double-integrator agent systems depends on not only the topology of the network but also the coupling strengths of relative position and velocity states between the neighboring agents.

In real communication environment, dynamical behaviors of agents in networks are determined by the interactions among them and their intrinsic dynamics (disturbances and unmodeled uncertainties of agent) [19], [20]. Protocols dealing with second-order consensus of multiagent systems with nonlinear dynamics have not been involved until the recent works [19], [20]. In [20], a kind of measurement for directed strongly connected graphs, i.e., general algebraic connectivity, was first introduced by Yu et al. The authors built the bridge between the general algebraic connectivity and the performance of reaching an agreement of the second-order multiagent systems with nonlinear dynamics. A similar problem has also been studied by Song et al. in [19] through the use of pinning control technique, and it is worth mentioning that the restriction on the aforementioned approach in which the interaction network is strongly connected is removed in [20]. There exists a common drawback in the literature, i.e., the network topology under investigation is fixed. However, practical networks are usually in uncertain communication environments [2]- [4], [14], [15], so the information flow between any pair of agents may be subject to failure with a certain probability in the real world. In such cases, the network topology is constant in some time intervals and randomly jumps to another topology when certain occasional events occur at some random moments. Therefore, it is important to study the system with random network topology, the existence of whose edge is probabilistic. Moreover, the dwell time of each topology is unknown in advance, and the weighted adjacent matrix is not necessarily nonnegative due to the probable existence of deteriorated communication channels in reality. Mathematically, dynamics of agents in such kind of networks can be modeled as a kind of arbitrarily fast switching nonlinear systems. As described previously, the study on the second-order dynamical consensus in multiagent systems with arbitrarily fast switching topologies is complicated and challenging, particularly when there exist isolated agents in some topologies in the switching sequence.

Motivated by the aforementioned discussions, this paper will focus on the second-order locally dynamical consensus of multiagent systems with nonlinear dynamics in the directed networks with arbitrarily fast switching topologies. In our designed framework, each link in the network, which represents the information flow between any pair of agents, could be subject to failure with a certain probability. Moreover, it is assumed that the dwell time of each topology is unknown in advance and the corresponding adjacency weighted matrix is not necessarily nonnegative due to the deteriorated communication channels. By the orthogonal decomposition method, the state vector of the resultant error dynamical system could be further decomposed as two transversal components, one of which evolves along the consensus manifold and the other evolves transversally with the consensus manifold. Thus, the problem to be solved is simplified as analyzing the locally asymptotical stability of a fast switching dynamical system with respect to the component that evolves transversally with the consensus manifold. The difficulty using Lyapunov theory is that there is no general method on how to construct a suitable Lyapunov function for such kind of fast switching systems. In what follows, by introducing the generalized matrix measure [25], [26], we instead make use of contraction and circle analysis methods [27], [30] to study the second-order locally dynamical consensus of multiagent systems with arbitrarily fast switching directed topologies in detail. Several easily verified criteria are also derived for reaching the second-order dynamical consensus. From our main results, to verify whether the locally dynamical consensus in a multiagent network with arbitrarily fast switching directed topologies can be achieved, we only need to validate the obtained criteria along each cycle which consists of some specific topologies. If all of the values are negative, then the consensus can be guaranteed. Moreover, we also find that, only if the position and velocity coupling strengths are sufficiently large, the arbitrarily fast switching can be tolerated. Finally, a numerical simulation is provided to illustrate the feasibility and effectiveness of our theoretical results. Moreover, the obtained results are quite powerful and can be further used to explore various switching cases for complex dynamical networks. The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Some necessary concepts and knowledge with respect to random graph theory are given, and problems are formulated in Section II. In Section III, the main results are provided. A numerical example is presented in Section IV to illustrate the effectiveness of the obtained theoretical results. Finally, this paper is concluded in Section V.

Notations: We use the following notations throughout this paper. Let R + be the set of positive real numbers. R n and R n×m denote the n-dimensional Euclidean space and the set of all n × m real matrices, respectively. For a vector u ∈ R n , its Euclidean norm (or called 2-norm) is defined as u = (u T u) 1/2 . I n and O n denote the n-dimensional identity matrix and zero matrix, respectively. Let e = [1, 1, . . . , 1] T . For a symmetric matrix A ∈ R m×m , the minimum and maximum eigenvalues are denoted by λ min (A) and λ max (A), respectively. In addition, the algebraic spectrum of A, e.g.,
div.formula: {λ i (A)} m i=1 , is or- dered so that λ min (A) = λ 1 (A) ≤ λ 2 (A) ≤ • • • ≤ λ m-1 (A)≤ λ m (A) = λ max (A).
div.p: The Kronecker product, denoted by ⊗, facilitates the manipulation of matrices with appropriate dimensions by the following properties: 1)
div.formula: (A ⊗ B)(C ⊗ D) = AC ⊗ BD and 2) (A ⊗ B) T = A T ⊗ B T . For a set M , |M | is used to denote its cardinality.

div.head: A. Random Graph
div.p: A graph consists of a set of vertices, each pair of which is endowed with an incidence relation represented by an edge. The set of vertices and edges of the graph G are denoted by V and E, respectively; in this case, we write G = (V, E). In our designed framework, for a random graph on N vertices, the existence of an edge between a pair of vertices in the set V = {1, 2, . . . , N} is determined randomly and independent of other edges with probability p = 0.5. The sample space (the set of all possible topologies) of such a random graph will be defined by M . Let m(t) be a topology indicator, i.e., m : R + → M . Let t k 's be the switching moments appearing in the running process of the time-varying dynamical network G(t), where t k ∈ R + , k = 1, 2, . . .. Thus, m(t) is a piecewise left continuous function, which keeps unchanged when t ∈ [t k , t k+1 ) and randomly jumps to another topology in M at t = t k+1 . Since there are totally 2C 2 N potential directed edges among N vertices, the cardinality of M , i.e., |M |, is bounded, and its upper bound is 2 2C 2 N . In this paper, we use the tool of random graph to describe a multiagent network whose directed topology switches arbitrarily fast. Specially, the existence (nonexistence) of a directed edge E ij ∈ E in the random graph G(t) is represented by an ordered pair of vertices (i, j), which practically means agent j can (cannot) receive the position and/or velocity information from agent i in the network. For a dynamical network G(t) with N vertices, we assign it an adjacency weighted matrix W = [w ij ] N ×N . Negative weights may also exist in W , which means the probable existence of deteriorated communication channels or natural disagreement of the child node over the information obtained from its parent node. If the one-way information channel between agent i and agent j is established successfully when t ∈ [t k , t k+1 ), the edge E ij exists and is naturally assigned a weight w ij when t ∈ [t k , t k+1 ). Meanwhile, the effect on agent i by the information received from agent j is a positive correlation with
div.formula: w ij when t ∈ [t k , t k+1 ). Supposing that W = [w ij ] N ×N is the weighted matrix of random graph G(t) at time t, we use L(m(t)) = [L ij (m(t))] N ×N to denote the corresponding Laplacian matrix of G(t), where L ij = -w ij if i = j and L ij = N k=1 w ik if i = j. The Laplacian matrix L is a zero row sums matrix; therefore, e = [1, 1, . . . , 1]
div.p: T is an eigenvector of L associated with the zero eigenvalue [15]. In addition, the rank of L is equal to N -1 if and only if, for an undirected graph, it is connected; for a directed graph, it contains a directed spanning tree [15]. Let t k s,i and t k f,i denote, respectively, the kth starting time and the kth ending time of topology i in M . Furthermore, suppose that 0
div.formula: < Δ 1,i = inf k {t k f,i -t k s,i } ≤ sup k {t k f,i -t k s,i } = Δ 2,i < +∞, i.e., the dwell time of topology i is in the interval [Δ 1,i , Δ 2,i ].

div.head: B. Problem Formulation
div.p: Suppose that there are N agents in the dynamical network G(t) and each one is an n-dimensional dynamical unit with second-order nonlinear dynamics. At time t, all agents are pairwise interconnected using the weighted and directional position and velocity state information based on the topology of G(t). The model of each agent through coupling can be described by
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ ẋi (t) = v i (t), vi (t) = f (x i (t), v i (t), t) -α N j=1 L ij (m(t)) B(t)x j (t) -β N j=1 L ij (m(t)) B(t)v j (t), i = 1, 2, . . . , N(1)
div.p: where
div.formula: x i (t) = (x i1 (t), . . . , x in (t)) T ∈ R n and v i (t) = (v i1 (t), . . . , v in (t)) T ∈ R n
div.p: are the position and velocity state vector of the ith agent, respectively; f : R n × R n × R + → R n is a continuously differentiable vector-valued function, which represents the inner nonlinear dynamics of uncoupled agent i; α > 0 and β > 0 stand for position and velocity coupling strengths between any two agents in the network; and B(t) ∈ R n×n is a semipositive definite diagonal matrix, modeling the time-varying inner coupling agents. At time t, L(m(t)) = (L ij (m(t))) N ×N is the Laplacian matrix of the dynamical network G(t), which switches arbitrarily fast.
Definition 1: The second-order nonlinear consensus in multiagent systems ( 1) is said to be local if, for any ε > 0, there exist a δ(ε) > 0 and a T > 0 such that
div.formula: x i (0) -x j (0) ≤ δ(ε) and v i (0) -v j (0) ≤ δ(ε) imply x i (t) -x j (t) ≤ ε and v i (t) -v j (t) ≤ ε for any t > T and i, j = 1, . . . , N.
div.p: If the second-order dynamical consensus of ( 1) is achieved in G(t), there exist two n-dimensional time-varying vectors s 1 (t) and s 2 (t) such that, for i = 1, 2, . . . , N, x i (t) = e ⊗ s 1 (t), v i (t) = e ⊗ s 2 (t), and
Here,
div.formula: s(t) = [s T 1 (t), s T 2 (t)]
div.p: T ∈ R 2n is called the consensus manifold. Generally, s(t) can be a nontrivial periodic orbit or even a chaotic attractor defined for finite dimensional systems. Subtracting ( 2) from ( 1) and noticing that all of the row sums of Laplacian matrix L(m(t)) are equal to zero, yield the following error dynamical system:

div.formula: xi (t) = x i (t) -s 1 (t) and vi (t) = v i (t) -s 2 (t), i = 1, 2, . . . , N.
div.p: Investigating the second-order locally nonlinear consensus of all agents in the network G(t) with arbitrarily fast switching topologies is equivalent to analyzing the locally asymptotical stability of switched nonlinear system (3). Thus, linearizing (3) around the consensus manifold s(t) leads to

We first decompose the state vector y(t) of ( 5) (neglecting the high-order term O(y(t), t)) into two components which are orthogonal to each other. One component evolves along the consensus manifold s(t), and the other evolves transversally to the consensus manifold s(t). Due to the fact that e ∈ R N , we denote its spanned subspace by A. On the other hand, each subspace of R N has only one orthogonal complementary subspace, so the orthogonal subspace of A uniquely exists. Suppose that this orthogonal complementary space A ⊥ is the column space of matrix V ∈ R N ×(N -1) that satisfies V T e = 0 and V T V = I N -1 , where V = (V 1 , V 2 , . . . , V N -1 ) consists of an array of N -1 basis vectors in R N . Obviously, R N = A ⊕ A ⊥ . Similarly, we also can expand this decomposition into R nN , i.e., R nN = B ⊕ B ⊥ , where B is the subspace spanned by e ⊗ I n and B ⊥ represents the orthogonal complement space spanned by V ⊗ I n . Note that the consensus state e ⊗ s(t) = 0 in the range of e ⊗ I n = 0 and then in the null space of V T ⊗ I n [21], [22]. Therefore, the state variable y(t) ∈ R 2nN can be decomposed into a component in the subspace B spanned by e ⊗ I n = 0 and a component in the subspace B ⊥ spanned by V T ⊗ I n as follows:

div.p: Similarly, the second subsystem can be expressed as

If η(t) → 0 as t → +∞, from (12), we know that y(t) will also approach to zero along the consensus manifold s(t). Thus, the second-order locally dynamical consensus in multiagent systems with arbitrarily fast switching topology can be achieved. The difficulty with Lyapunov theory is that there is no general method on how to construct a Lyapunov function for such kind of arbitrarily fast switching dynamical systems. In the following section, we will use the methods of contraction and circle analysis to study under what conditions the state η(t) of arbitrarily fast switchings system (13) locally asymptotically decays to zero.

Remark 1: Our results are based on the orthogonal decomposition method. Therefore, the existence of the decomposition matrix V ∈ R N ×(N -1) satisfying V T e = 0 and V T V = I N -1 is very essential. If an underlying undirected graph associated with the weighted matrix 0.5(W + W T ) contains a directed spanning tree, the N -1 eigenvectors associated with N -1 nonzero eigenvalues of the obtained connected graph's Laplacian matrix L are real vectors; then, we can use the N -1 normalized real eigenvectors to construct the decomposition matrix V . Some definitions are given for convenient analysis.
Definition 2 [23]: The matrix measure of a complex square matrix
div.formula: C = (c ij ) ∈ C n×n is defined as μ θ (C) = lim ε→0 + ( I n + εC θ -1/ε), in which . θ is an induced ma- trix norm. When matrix norms C 1 = max j n i=1 |c ij |, C 2 = [λ max (C T C)]
div.p: 1/2 , and C ∞ = max i n j=1 |c ij |, we can obtain the matrix measures:
div.formula: μ 1 (C) = max j {Re(c jj ) + n i=1,i =j |c ij |}, μ 2 (C) = (1/2)λ max (C * + C), and μ ∞ (C) = max i {Re(c ii ) + n j=1,j =i |c ij |}, respectively
div.p: , where C * is the complex conjugate transpose of a complex matrix and Re(C) denotes the real part of a complex C.

Definition 3 [25]: For any continuously differentiable nonlinear function f (x), the generalized matrix measure of f (x), μθ (f (x), CS), in a compact set CS is of the form μθ (f (x), CS) = sup x∈CS {μ θ (∂f /∂x)}, and the generalized matrix norm f (x) θ,CS = sup x∈CS { ∂f /∂x θ }, where . θ is an induced matrix norm that is the same as that in Definition 1 and θ = {1, 2, ∞}.

div.head: III. LOCAL STABILITY UNDER ARBITRARILY FAST SWITCHINGS
div.p: Before giving the main results, we present the following lemmas.
A logical path in the arbitrarily fast switched system (13) can be described by a topology sequence
div.formula: m(t k 1 ), m(t k 2 ), . . . , m(t k 1+n ). A finite logical path m(t k 1 ), m(t k 2 ), . . . , m(t k 1+n ) is closed if m(t k 1 ) = m(t k 1+n ). A closed path CP = m(t k 1 ), m(t k 2 ), . .

div.head: . , m(t k 1+n
div.p: ), in which no states appear more than once except for the one that is the first and the last is a cycle [27]. We can find all types of cycles by using the knowledge from graph theory. We state the following lemmas.
Lemma 1 [27]: Every closed path is composed of some cycles.

Lemma 2 [27]: Suppose that n + 1 states m(t k 1 ), m(t k 2 ), . . . , m(t k 1+n ) belong to a set which is composed of n different states m(t k i ), 1 ≤ i ≤ n. Then, there exists at least one cycle in the logical path m(t k 1 ), m(t k 2 ), . . . m(t k 1+n ).

In the following, we will derive some sufficient conditions by studying the convergence of η T (t)η(t) through using the contraction and circle analysis [27], [30] instead of constructing a Lyapunov function.
From (13), we have
div.formula: dη T (t)η(t) dt = η T (t) A T (s 1 , s 2 , m(t)) + A (s 1 , s 2 , m(t))) η(t) (14)

div.p: We are in a position to state our main results.

Theorem 1: The second-order locally dynamical consensus of multiagent systems (1) with arbitrarily fast switching directed topologies can be achieved if there exists a compact set SCS ⊆ CS such that SCS contains η * = 0, and for each cycle LC(j)(1 ≤ j ≤ θ) in the switching sequences, we have α
div.formula: (j) = i∈LC(j) μ2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS)Δ * i < 0, where Δ * i = Δ 2,i for i ∈ N 1 and Δ * i = Δ 1,i for i ∈ N 2 with N 1 = {i|μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) ≥ 0} and N 2 = {i|μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) < 0}.
div.p: Proof: Without loss of generality, it is assumed that the switching sequence can be partitioned as m 1 , m 2 , . . . , m p , a closed path, denoted as CP, and m l+1 , m l+2 , . . . , m l+q , where m 1 = m(t 0 ), m l+q = m(t), p ≤ |M |, and q ≤ |M |. It is worth mentioning that the partition is not unique. According to Lemma 1, the closed path CP is composed of some cycles, denoted by LC (1), LC(2), . . . , LC(θ), where |LC(j)| ≤ M , and there are no subcycles in LC(j), j ∈ {1, 2, . . . , θ}. Let t s,CP and t f,CP , respectively, represent the start time and the ending time of the closed path CP. We can get that m p is the former topology of m(t s,CP ) and m l+1 is the latter topology of m(t f,CP ).
By (14) and the definition of generalized matrix measure, we have

div.p: The |M | potential topologies can be divided as the following two sets:
Therefore, ( 17) is equivalent to the following two inequalities:

div.p: Let t j (j = 1, 2, . . .) represent all of the switching moments in the closed path CP; by ( 17)-( 20), we know that
div.formula: η(t j ) ≤ i∈ST (t s,CP ;t j ) exp {μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i } × η(t s,CP )(21)
div.p: where ST (t s,CP ; t j ) = {i|i is the node (topology) in the path from m(t s,CP ) to m(t j )}.
The following two cases are considered. Case 1: There is no cycle in the path from m(t s,CP ) to m(t j ). Then, by (21), the following inequalities hold:
div.formula: η(t j ) ≤ i∈N 1 ST (t s,CP ;t j ) exp{μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i } × i∈N 2 ST (t s,CP ;t j ) exp{μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS)Δ * i } × η(t s,CP ) ≤ i∈N 1 exp{μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS)Δ * i } × i∈N 2 exp{μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i } × η(t s,CP ) ≤ i∈N 1 exp{μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i } × η(t s,CP ) . (22
div.p: Case 2: There exist cycles LC(1 ), LC(2 ), . . . , LC(θ ) in the path from m(t s,CP ) to m(t j ). Using (21), we have (23), shown at the bottom of the page, where α = max
Therefore, the inequality ( 22) always holds. In particular, when t j = t f,CP , we can get
div.formula: η(t f,CP ) ≤ α NC(t s,CP ;t f,CP ) × i∈N 1 exp {μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i } η(t s,CP )(24)

η(t j ) ≤ k 0 ∈{1 ,2 ,...,θ } i∈LC(k 0 ) exp {μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i } × ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ i∈ ST (t s,CP ;t j )- k 0 ∈{1 ,2 ,...,θ } (ST (t s,LC(k 0 ) ;t f,LC(k 0 ) ) exp {μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i } ⎫ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎬ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎭ η(t s,CP ) = exp ⎛ ⎝ k 0 ∈{1 ,2 ,...,θ } i∈LC(k 0 ) (μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i ) ⎞ ⎠ × i∈N 1 ST (t s,CP ;t j )- k 0 ∈{1 ,2 ,...,θ } (ST (t s,LC(k 0 ) ;t f,LC(k 0 ) ) exp {μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i } × i∈N 2 ST (t s,CP ;t j )- k 0 ∈{1 ,2 ,...,θ } (ST (t s,LC(k 0 ) ;t f,LC(k 0 ) ) exp {μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i } η(t s,CP ) < exp ⎛ ⎝ k 0 ∈{1 ,2 ,...,θ } α(k 0 ) ⎞ ⎠ i∈N 1 exp {μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i } η(t s,CP ) ≤ α θ i∈N 1 exp {μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i } η(t s,CP ) < i∈N 1 exp {μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i } η(t s,CP )(23)
div.p: where NC(t s,CP ; t f,CP ) denotes the total number of cycles in the closed path from m(t s,CP ) to m(t f,CP ).
Similarly, we have
div.formula: η(t s,CP ) ≤ i∈ST (t 0 ;t s,CP ) exp {μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i } × η(t 0 ) ≤exp max i∈N 1 (μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS)) (p+1)Δ * × η(t 0 )(25)
div.p: where
div.formula: Δ * = max i∈M {Δ * i }. When t ≥ t f,CP , similarly, we obtain η(t) ≤ i∈ST (t f,CP ;t) exp {μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * i } × η(t s,CP ) ≤ exp max i∈N 1 (μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS)) (q + 1)Δ * × η(t f,CP ) . (26
div.p: Combining ( 24)-( 26), for all t ≥ t 0 , we have
div.formula: η(t) ≤α NC(t 0 ;t) exp max i∈N 1 (μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS)) × (p + q + 2)Δ * η(t 0 ) ≤α NC(t 0 ;t) exp 2 max i∈N 1 (μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS)) × (|M | + 1) Δ * η(t 0 ) . (27
div.p: The following task is to prove that η(t) ∈ SCS for t 0 ≤ t ≤ t k , where t k (k = 1, 2, . . .) are all of the switching moments in the switching sequence. This will be done by induction method.

For t 0 ≤ t ≤ t 1 , suppose that there exists a t * such that η(t * ) ∈ SCS, i.e., η(t * ) > R. If η(t 0 ) ∈ SCS, then there exists a t * * such that η(t * * ) = R and η(t) ≤ R, t ∈ [t 0 , t * * ]. From (13) and the definition of generalized matrix measure, we know that (28) holds for all t ∈ [t 0 , t * * ].
By (28), we have
which contradicts with η(t * * ) = R. Thus, η(t) ∈ SCS holds for t 0 ≤ t ≤ t 1 . Moreover, if
div.formula: R 0 = R max i∈N 1 (exp (μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * )) × 1 exp 2 max i∈N 1 (μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS)) (|M | + 1) Δ * (30)
div.p: and η(t 0 ) ≤ R 0 , we can get
div.formula: η(t 1 ) ≤ exp(μ 2 (A (s 1 , s 2 , m(t 0 )) , SCS) (t 1 -t 0 )) × η(t 0 ) ≤ max i∈N 1 (exp (μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS)Δ * )) × η(t 0 ) ≤ max i∈N 1 (exp(μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS)Δ * ))R 0 = R exp 2 max i∈N 1 (μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS))(|M |+1)Δ * <R. (31
div.p: Supposing that η(t) ∈ SCS holds for t 0 ≤ t ≤ t N , then we will show η(t) ∈ SCS also holds for t N ≤ t ≤ t N +1 . By (27), we obtain
div.formula: η(t N +1 ) ≤ α NC(t 0 ;t N +1 ) × exp max i∈N 1 (μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS)) × (p + q + 2)Δ * η(t 0 ) ≤ α NC(t 0 ;t N +1 ) × exp 2 max i∈N 1 (μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS)) × (|M | + 1) Δ * η(t 0 ) ≤ R max i∈N 1 (exp (μ 2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , i), SCS) Δ * )) <R. (32
div.p: By the aforementioned equation, we have that, if η(t 0 ) ≤ R 0 , then η(t) < R for all t > t 0 , i.e., η(t) ∈ SCS. Note that NC(t 0 ; t) → +∞ as t → +∞. Thus, we can see that, if the initial condition satisfies η(t 0 ) ≤ R 0 , then lim t→∞ η(t) = 0.

It is obtained from (12) that ȳ(t) will also approach to zero along the consensus manifold s(t). Thus, the secondorder locally dynamical consensus of multiagent systems with arbitrarily fast switching topologies can be achieved. The proof is thus completed.
Based on Theorem 1, we can immediately derive the following corollaries; here, the proof is omitted.

Corollary 1: The second-order locally dynamical consensus of multiagent systems (1) with arbitrarily fast switching directed topologies can be achieved if there exists a compact set SCS ⊆ UCS such that SCS contains η * = 0 and for all m(t) ∈ M , α(m(t)) = μ2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , m(t)), SCS) < 0.

Remark 2: According to the expression of A(s 1 , s 2 , m(t)), for all potential topologies m(t) ∈ M , we can see that α(m(t)) < 0 can be easily guaranteed by selecting sufficiently large coupling strengths α and β. That is to say, the arbitrarily fast switching directed topologies can be effectively tolerated, and the consensus can be achieved for all agents in the network. Throughout this paper, we always assume that the states of all agents in the network are bounded. The network after coupling may be divergent even if the isolated agent is bounded. The boundedness of the whole coupling network, however, is not the main focus of this paper.
The fixed topology can be considered as a special case of switching topology; therefore, we can get the following.

Corollary 2: The second-order locally dynamical consensus of multiagent systems (1) with fixed topology m can be achieved if there exists a compact set SCS ⊆ UCS such that SCS contains η * = 0 and α(m) = μ2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , m), SCS) < 0.

div.head: IV. ILLUSTRATIVE EXAMPLE
div.p: In this section, a numerical simulation example is presented to illustrate the effectiveness of the obtained theoretical results.

Example: For convenience, we assume that there are a total of five agents in the dynamical network G(t), and the dwell time of each topology in the switching sequence is randomly distributed in the interval [0.2, 0.7]. Each agent is equipped with a second-order oscillator with nonlinear dynamics. At time t, all agents are coupled by position and velocity states with other agents according to the topology of the network G(t). Suppose the agents' inner coupling matrix B = I 3 . Through coupling, the nonlinear dynamics of agent i can be described by
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ ẋi (t) = v i (t) vi (t) = f (v i (t)) -α 5 j=1 L ij (m(t)) x j (t) -β 5 j=1 L ij (m(t)) v j (t)(33)
div.p: for i = 1, 2, . . . 5, where
div.formula: x i = (x i1 , x i2 , x i3 ) T , v i = (v i1 , v i2 , v i3 ) T , f (v i ) = (v i2 , v i3 , -cv i1 -bv i2 -av i3 + v 2 i3 )
div.p: T , and a, b, c are constants. In particular, when a = 0.44, b = 1.1, and c = 1, the second-order isolated oscillator (α = β = 0) depicts a chaotic attractor [24]. It is assumed that the link weights among agents is Due to the boundedness of the chaotic trajectory, the generalized matrix measure α(m(t)) = μ2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , m(t)), SCS) < locally dynamical consensus over the arbitrarily fast switching network is achieved. Before the dynamic consensus is achieved, the consensus state vector s(t) = [s T 1 (t), s T 2 (t)] T is unknown to us. Therefore, the generalized matrix measure α(m(t)) = μ2 (A(s 1 , s 2 , m(t)), SCS) for those topologies m(t) in which the consensus is reached could not be precisely computed. However, we still can use one of the agents' state vectors to substitute the consensus state vector s(t) to approximately estimate the index α(m(t)). Using the states of all agents to replace s(t), respectively, the time-varying generalized matrix measure is shown in Fig. 4. In Fig. 4, we can see that the generalized matrix measures are always negative and near each other by selecting suitable coupling strengths, i.e., α = 20 and β = 20.

In addition, the link weight between two agents denotes how to update the designed consensus algorithms. In general, we do not require the link weights to be nonnegative. However, in practice, negative weights may usually imply the existence of deteriorated communication channels or natural disagreement of the child node over the information obtained from its parent node. It is noted that, in our experiments, we have considered the case in which some communication links have negative weights, e.g., W 23 = -0.4799. In the simulation, other parameters keep unchanged. It is found that the second-order locally dynamical consensus over the fast switching network G(t) can be also achieved. We omit giving the simulation results due to limited space. Therefore, the obtained results are more practical in the application of engineering.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: The problem of second-order consensus of multiagent systems with nonlinear dynamics, especially with random switching directed topologies, is very difficult. There are still few works involve in the second-order nonlinear consensus of multiagent systems with arbitrarily fast switching topologies. The traditional Lyapunov stability theory may fail to analyze the stability of such kinds of fast switching nonlinear systems. By using local linearization technique, generalized matrix measure, contraction analysis, and cycle analysis methods, the secondorder locally dynamical consensus is investigated. From our theoretical results and simulations, it is found that, under sufficiently large coupling strengths, the arbitrarily fast switching can be effectively tolerated. It is worth mentioning that the global consensus of second-order agents with nonlinear dynamics over random networks by time-delay couplings is still an open problem. Further work also includes the boundedness of the agents' state of the whole coupling network.

Fig.2(a) and (b) shows the time evolution of consensus position and velocity errors, respectively. Fig.3(a) and (b) shows the time evolution of logarithms with regard to the consensus position and velocity errors, respectively. It is easy to see that, by choosing suitable coupling strengths, the second-order

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
div.p: The authors would like to thank the Associate Editor and anonymous reviewers for their constructive comments, based on which the presentation of this paper has been greatly improved.

At present, he is a Professor at Southwest University and the Dean of College of Electronics and Information Engineering. He has published more than 200 international journal and conference papers. His current research interests include neural networks, nonlinear dynamical systems, bifurcation and chaos, and cryptography Tingwen Huang received the B.S. degree in mathematics from Southwest Normal University

respStmt.orgName: Huaqing Li received the B.S. degree in information and computer science from Chongqing University of Posts and Telecommunications ; Chinese University of Hong Kong ; City University of Hong Kong ; City University of Hong Kong ; Professor at Chongqing University ; He was a Lecturer with Jiangsu University

biblStruct.note: He has been an Associate Professor with Texas A&M University. where he was a Visiting Assistant Professor from January to July 2003 and an Assistant Professor from August 2003 to June 2009. His current research interests include neural networks, complex networks, and chaos and dynamics of systems and operator semigroups and their applications
